article:
[[Helicobacter pylori]] virulence factor 'CagA' (cytotoxin-associated gene A) is
a 120-145kDa protein encoded on the 40kb cag pathogenicity island (PAI). H. pylori strains can be divided into CagA positive
or negative strains, of which around 60% of H. pylori isolates in Western
countries are positive, whereas the majority of East Asian isolates are
negative.

The cag PAI also encodes for a type 4 secretion system which is used to "inject"
CagA into a target cell upon H. pylori attachment. After translocation, CagA
localises to the inner surface of the cell membrane and undergoes tyrosine
phosphorylation by Src family kinases (e.g. Fyn and Lyn).
